message: All the best to you and your family in 2017.
Here are some highlights from 2016. I'm looking forward to 2017. Follow me on Instagram @JohnBoozman. #best9of2016

As the 115th Congress convenes, I want to thank you for giving me the opportunity to continue to serve the great state of Arkansas in the U.S. Senate. I am incredibly grateful for the trust you have placed in me and I am eager to start working toward accomplishing the goals we have laid out in the last year.

Some scenes from today's swearing-in for the 115th Congress. Such a blessing to have my family, friends and supporters with me for this important occasion. The Bible pictured in here is the one on which I took the oath of office today. It was my dad's Bible that he carried with him during World War II.
I'm pleased to know the students at Eureka Springs Elementary School received their new American flag. Thank you for the nice note.

I met with U.S. Environmental Protection Agency nominee Oklahoma Attorney General E. Scott Pruitt yesterday. I appreciate his commitment to renew common sense to the agency and ensure the policies created follow the rule of law. I look forward to working with him to ensure the EPA uses a smart, balanced approach to protect our environment.
The 115th Congress started this week. I’ve received many questions about what our priorities will be and how we can accomplish them, so I answered some of those questions in my most recent column.

With weeks left before the end of his presidency, President Obama continues his irresponsible campaign promise to close Gitmo. Here’s why this is a problem – former detainees have returned to the battlefield and are responsible for the deaths of Americans. This is a threat to our national security. Read more in this blog post http://bit.ly/2jcMjeX

I joined Agri-Pulse Communications, Inc. Open Mic to discuss the 115th Congress and how I'll be helping the agriculture industry and rural America. We talked about efforts to roll back regulations like the EPA’s Waters of the United States rule, the upcoming Farm Bill and the opportunity we have to trade with Cuba. You can listen to the interview here.

Arkansas State Senator Stanley Russ showed kindness and consideration to everyone he met. I was pleased to recognize his life in Congressional Record as Arkansans today celebrated his life and contributions to our state.

In honor of #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay I want to express my gratitude and appreciation to all those in the law enforcement community in Arkansas and across the country. Your sacrifice and service to your community is remarkable and we are thankful for the work you do and your willingness to run towards danger to protect your family, friends and neighbors.

If you missed my interview on KASU Public Radio this morning you can listen to it here. We talked about priorities of the 115th Congress and the confirmation process of President-elect Trump's cabinet nominees. Listen here.

The Obama administration’s free spending ways have dramatically increased our national debt and produced an economic legacy of sluggish job growth, stagnant wages and a reduction in personal savings for hardworking families across the country. We need the right people and the right policy to get our fiscal house in order. I am confident that Congressman Mulvaney is committed to the course correction we need to put our nation back on a fiscally responsible, sustainable path.

Passage of this budget resolution is the first of several steps that Congress will take to keep our promise to repeal and replace Obamacare.  Obamacare has driven up costs, busted our budget, stifled job growth and raised taxes on hardworking Arkansans. It has created more problems than it solves and it has to go.  Senate Republicans are committed to a careful and orderly transition to a patient-centered health care system that truly is affordable, not just in name but in practice, and actually works for the American people.

Congratulations to Robert Christian Parker of Fort Smith and Shreya Majagi of Rogers who were selected to represent Arkansas at the United States Senate Youth Program. I look forward to visiting with these young Arkansans in March when they're in Washington.

Today we celebrate the 231st anniversary of the passage of the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom, which was written by Thomas Jefferson and served as the model for the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment. Our ability to worship freely is a cornerstone of American public life and I am thankful our founders had the foresight to enshrine it in the Bill of Rights. Happy Religious Freedom Day!

Pleased to be in Gillett for great Arkansas traditions, the Coon Supper and the Berry Pre-Coon Reception. It was great seeing Arkansas Commissioner of State Lands John Thurston, Governor Asa Hutchinson, Arkansas Auditor of State Andrea Lea and Lieutenant Governor Tim Griffin.

There are only a few individuals in our nation's history that everyone agrees made our country better. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is one of them. I'm honored to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at the 2017 Interfaith Prayer Breakfast hosted by the Arkansas Martin Luther King, Jr. Commission. We continue to be reminded of his vision for a free and equal country. His work and tireless advocacy continue to inspire us today.

I look forward to celebrating with Arkansans who are making the trip to the nation’s capital to celebrate the historic occasion of the swearing-in of Donald Trump, our nation’s 45th President. This is a ticket and program attendees to the ceremony will receive.

These Gosnell High School students, faculty and parents are in for an exciting and historic time in Washington this week. They are excited to witness history and attend the inauguration. I'm pleased to join Senator Tom Cotton to provide these Arkansans with tickets to witness the swearing-in of our 45th President.
I joined KFFB 106.1 FM to discuss the confirmation process for cabinet secretaries and the first steps Congress took to repeal Obamacare. You can listen to the two-part interview here.

I had a great start to my day meeting with Arkansas students from Cabot High School and Smackover High School who are in Washington as participants of the Close Up - Washington D.C. Educational Programs. This great program gives students a first-hand look at our government in action and shows how they can be engaged in the process.

As a member of the Environment and Public Works (EPW) Committee I had the opportunity to question Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) administrator nominee Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt during his confirmation hearing. I asked him about transparency at the agency and using sound science to base the policies crafted by EPA.

In my weekly column I highlight the importance of this historic week in our government as we prepare for the inauguration of our nation’s 45th President. The peaceful transition of power is America’s unique political legacy and something citizens should be grateful for and never take for granted.

Following countless meetings and discussions, I am pleased that we have now identified a path forward, which preserves the 188th Wing, Arkansas Air National Guard's long-admired presence in the Fort Smith community and addresses the concerns of the Fort Smith Regional Airport - both of which are vital to the community and our nation.

As we celebrate the inauguration of the 45th President of the United States, we should all pause and take a moment to appreciate just how durable and dynamic the American experiment has been. The inaugural activities are an occasion to remember how exceptional our nation is and what sets it apart from so many others. I'm excited to welcome so many Arkansans to Washington to celebrate this historic occasion.
NA

The Senate confirmed our new Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security. The transition period is over and the President deserves to have his cabinet selections in place. General James Mattis and General John Kelly are two men of integrity who will serve our nation extremely well in these key national security positions. I encourage my colleagues to move quickly to confirm the remaining cabinet positions so that President Trump can begin to work with us to address the important issues facing our nation.

We are all so proud of the performance that the Russellville Cyclone Band gave during the Inaugural Parade. I had a chance to walk these bright, talented kids through the Capitol today and show them all the history of this great building.

Pleased to have the newest edition of Hawgs Illustrated join the newspapers and magazines on the coffee table in my office. I enjoyed reminiscing about my time as an Arkansas Razorback Football player with WholeHogSports.com

As a member of the Senate Budget Committee I had an opportunity to question Office of Management and Budget Director nominee U.S. Representative Mick Mulvaney during his confirmation hearing today about government spending and the need to reduce our nation’s debt. I highlighted the broken budget and appropriations process and the problems plaguing government agencies to fight wasteful spending when faced with budget uncertainty. I agree that we must, as Rep. Mulvaney says, "reinvigorate" the appropriations process. This will ultimately save taxpayer dollars.

It's National School Choice Week. I had a great discussion via Skype with Don Tyson School of Innovation students and staff about the importance of school choice. I'm proud to support school choice policies and the opportunities they offer Arkansas students and families.

I had a very good visit with Dr. Shulkin last night where he reaffirmed his commitment to modernizing the VA and bringing accountability to the department while ensuring our veterans have access to all the benefits they have earned. I've always appreciated Dr. Shulkin’s responsiveness to Arkansas veterans during his tenure as undersecretary for health and will support his nomination to lead the department. I am confident that as Secretary, he will strive to ensure our veterans get the timely, quality care they deserve.

Wallace Cunningham remembers listening to President Franklin Roosevelt’s “Day of Infamy” speech after the Pearl Harbor attack with his high school classmates. On his 18th birthday he enlisted in the Army Air Corps. He deployed to Europe with the 42nd Air Depot Group, landing on Omaha Beach a few weeks after the D-Day invasion and beginning the arduous journey through France. His unit was in Reims, France when the Germans surrendered there, ending the war in Europe. I'm proud to recognize his service and sacrifice on behalf of our nation. I'll submit his stories to the Library of Congress Veterans History Project so future generations can hear about his service to our nation.

Our Constitution is important to the American experiment and the success of our country because it preserves our rights and establishes parameters for what our government can and cannot do. I shared my love for the First Amendment in this #WeLoveTheConstitution video to celebrate our nation's guiding document. Join me and others in celebrating our love for the Constitution.

I support the right to life. Thank you to the thousands of Americans who will #MarchforLife in the nation’s capital today opposing the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion. I am proud to be a voice for the voiceless and fight to affirm that the unborn deserve the most basic of human rights.

Soldiers from the 1st Battalion, 153rd Infantry Regiment of the 39th Infantry Brigade of the Arkansas National Guard are finalizing mobilization activities at Fort Bliss, Texas. It was an honor to join the Adjutant General of the Arkansas National Guard, Congressman Steve Womack and Congressman Bruce Westerman  to visit with these men and women as they prepare for their overseas mission. These soldiers are making tremendous sacrifices in defense of our nation and, on behalf of the people of Arkansas, I am grateful for this opportunity to share our appreciation for their selfless service. I am proud of these soldiers and pleased to hear about their successful training. My prayers are with them and their families as they deploy and carry out their mission.

Over the weekend, I released a statement on the executive actions that President Trump took on Friday.    It has become apparent that many people in Arkansas and across the country are concerned that our immigration and refugee policies are vulnerable and that our generosity could be taken advantage of by radical terrorist groups like ISIS who wish to harm Americans. I am looking forward to working with the capable leaders at the Departments of State and Homeland Security to craft and implement policies that ensure that we are maintaining the highest level of security. For more, see the statement below:   "Protecting our national security must be a top priority. Our intelligence community and citizens in communities across Arkansas and the United States lack confidence in the programs we use to vet refugees fleeing from persecution and war-torn countries like Syria. We need reasonable measures that allow us to evaluate safety checks for people coming into our country. I have great confidence in Secretary Kelly and look forward to working with him to secure our borders. This is best achieved by working with Congress and the appropriate agencies to alleviate unintended consequences.”
I'm proud to co-host the National Prayer Breakfast with U.S. Senator Chris Coons. Read our column in the Washington Examiner about the importance of this special occasion.

Little Rock Rabbi Barry Block delivered the opening prayer in the U.S. Senate today as the guest chaplain. I am grateful that he accepted my invitation to lead the Senate with his spiritual guidance and appreciate his prayer for our country and its leaders. Rabbi Block serves as leader of Congregation B’nai Israel, Arkansas’s largest Jewish congregation.

Millions of Americans went to their polling places on election day to make their voices heard on the type of jurist they want serving on the Supreme Court. They decided to put their trust in President Trump to fill the Court’s vacant seat.  I am encouraged by how well-respected Judge Gorsuch is in legal circles and how highly experts speak of his intellect, experience and temperament which are all important qualities for the job.  Now that the President has made his selection, we will move forward with the confirmation process. It is my sincere hope that all of my colleagues, regardless of party, will respect the will of the voters and treat him fairly during the confirmation process.

The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee held a business meeting today to consider the nomination of Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to lead the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Democrat members of the committee refused to attend the meeting, stalling the nomination process. In 2009, the Senate confirmed seven of President Obama’s nominees on day one – and nearly all of them within two weeks. Today, the 13th day of the Trump administration, the Senate will hold its fifth confirmation vote.
The National Prayer Breakfast is underway. As co-chair of this year's event, I will be speaking shortly. Watch live here.

I'm pleased to join Senator Heidi Heitkamp to reintroduce our bill to help level the playing field for Arkansas farmers and exporters while simultaneously exposing Cubans to American ideals, values and products. Jeff Rutledge, a Newport, Arkansas rice farmer and president of the Arkansas Rice Council said this about the bill: “Being able to sell our commodities to Cuba just as easily as we sell to other markets like Mexico and Canada would be huge, especially for U.S.-grown rice. Senator Boozman’s bill would strip away the regulatory red tape and allow us to compete in the Cuban market just like we do everywhere else.”
In Case You Missed It: As co-chair of the National Prayer Breakfast, I was honored to introduce the Keynote Speaker Senate Chaplain Barry Black. I appreciated his inspirational message on prayer.
I answered listener questions and shared what the Senate is working on this week with KASU Public Radio this morning. If you missed the interview you can listen to it in its entirety here.

Today I met with the nominee for Secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, former Georgia Governor Sonny Perdue. With a background in agriculture and as a veterinarian, Governor Perdue has a unique understanding of the opportunities and challenges our farmers and ranchers face each day. We had a good conversation about the importance of agriculture to Arkansas and the hurdles our producers face in providing a safe and abundant food supply that helps feed the world. We discussed policies to open access for agriculture trade with Cuba and the need to ensure that the farm safety net works for Arkansas and all regions of the country as we begin to craft the next farm bill. Governor Perdue is very well-respected, and I look forward to working with him to address the needs of our agriculture community.

At an Air Force Association briefing this morning, director of the Air National Guard, Lt Gen “Catfish” Rice, talked about the great work being done at the Little Rock Air Force Base, Ark. to train our cyber warriors. This week we welcomed the first class of the new cyber course. The modular training will provide our airmen with the adaptive instruction they need in a dynamic domain.

As chairman of the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee, I was pleased to meet with United States Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kelly yesterday. We'll be working together to ensure we have the resources necessary to protect our national security.

As a former school board member and the father of three daughters who were educated in the public school system, I understand how important it is to have education decisions made at the local level. Betsy DeVos shares this value.  Betsy DeVos will advocate for all schools, public and private, and will ensure that schools are accountable to the states, not a national school board. She is committed to implementing the laws as Congress wrote them, which will return decision-making control for our classrooms to Arkansas’s communities where it belongs.

Senate Democrats “are slow-walking the installation of President Trump’s Cabinet to a historic degree” according to Politico. It’s time to stop obstructing the Cabinet confirmation process so the president can have a functioning team to provide him with the information and guidance he needs, and deserves, to carry out the work he was elected to do. Read more in my weekly column.

Are you a college student interested in learning more about the workings of the United States Senate and federal legislation affecting Arkansans? If so, you should consider applying to intern in any of my seven offices across Arkansas or my Washington, D.C. office. I am accepting applications for summer internships now through March 1st. Learn more about these exciting opportunities here:  https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/internships

It was great start to Monday by Skyping with fifth graders at  Jonesboro Visual and Performing Arts Magnet PATHS Group.  These students asked great questions. I hope this inspires these young Arkansans to a life of public service and to give back to the community. I appreciate the opportunity to connect with these students and share with them about my work in Washington.

If you're planning a trip to Washington, DC & are interested in touring the US Capitol or other sites, my office would love to arrange tours to help you make the most of the experience. Reach out here so we can assist you:   https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/visiting-washington-d-c

Dr. Shulkin understands that we have a shared responsibility to ensure the brave men and women who have served our nation have access to all the benefits and quality care they have earned. He is committed to modernizing VA and bringing accountability to a department, that for too long, operated in the dark.  We have reaffirmed our commitment to our veterans through the reforms included in CHOICE Act and other legislative initiatives. I am eager to work with Dr. Shulkin to build on that momentum and on additional efforts moving forward. I am confident that as Secretary, he will strive to ensure every veteran, no matter where he or she lives, has access to the timely, quality care they deserve.

I know a lot of Arkansans rely on Rhea Lana events to buy affordable children's clothes, furniture and toys, but an unnecessary and burdensome Department of Labor regulation is unfairly targeting this business model. That's why I joined Senator Tom Cotton and Congressman French Hill to introduce commonsense legislation that preserves this innovative business model for consignment events and protects parents from unfair federal regulations that limit their ability to save money on items children quickly outgrow.

Here are some of the creative Valentines that Arkansas elementary students made for our veterans. As part of National Salute to Veterans Patients week my staff was happy to help distribute these sweet notes in support of our veterans.

Arkansans who work in the agriculture sector, the largest contributor to our state’s economy, play an important role in helping us live up to our nickname of the Natural State. Our farmers and ranchers understand this and are excellent stewards of the environment from which they earn their livelihood. Unfortunately, they are often boxed out of voluntary conservation programs to help accomplish this goal. Our bill can help them protect our shared resources by removing the bureaucratic barriers that keep family farmers from participating in these programs.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is a rogue agency with no accountability to the American people. That's why I helped introduce legislation that would provide Congress oversight of this agency through the appropriations process.
I'm pleased to announce that I will serve as chairman of three key subcommittees this Congress which will enable me to be a strong voice for Arkansas.

Herman Shirley, a lifelong North Little Rock resident, graduated high school after WWII ended but wanted to take advantage of the education assistance offered to service members so he enlisted in the Army. Shirley was stationed in Occupied Japan. He supported the mission to interrogate high ranking Japanese military officers as to their planning and execution of the War in the Pacific. I thank him for his service to our country. I'll submit his stories to the Library of Congress Veterans History Project so future generations can hear about his service to our nation.

I regularly host telephone town halls from my Washington, D.C. office. These events allow me to reach thousands of Arkansans in a live, interactive town hall meeting conducted over the telephone at the touch of a button. This is a convenient way to talk with Arkansans about issues important to families, businesses and the future of our country. I find that telephone town halls are a great way to engage with Arkansans while voting in Washington. I look forward to our next telephone town hall on Monday, February 27 at 7:30 p.m. CT. Click the link to sign up.

Springdale School District Superintendent Dr. Jim Rollins has helped the school district meet the challenges of a growing and diverse population. I congratulate him on earning the distinction as Education Week's 2017 Leaders to Learn From. I appreciate his leadership and dedication to education, students and the community.

I was pleased to recognize Sealed Air Corp. Rogers employees Andy Morrison and Greg Williams today for their support of co-workers who serve in the National Guard and Reserves. I was honored to present plaques from the Secretary of Defense to them on behalf of Employer Support for the Guard and Reserve (ESGR). Morrison and Williams were nominated by two National Guardsmen who work at Sealed Air Rogers. The ESGR is a Department of Defense program established in 1972 to promote understanding between Reserve Component Service members and their civilian employers. Jason Curton, Group Performance Leader, accepted the award on behalf of Greg Williams. I am grateful that Sealed Air Rogers and these great Arkansans are there to back up our men and women who protect and defend us.

Interns play an important role in my office. Click below to learn more about the opportunities to intern in my Washington, Little Rock, Fort Smith, Lowell, Jonesboro, El Dorado, Stuttgart or Mountain Home office. The deadline to apply is March 1.

Arkansas members of the American Legion, Disabled Veterans of America and Veterans of Foreign Wars joined my staff to submit the oral history projects and receive an overview of the Library of Congress Veterans History Project. The memories of 21 Arkansas veterans became part of the world’s largest oral history archive. Special thanks to Har-Ber High School students for the interviews they conducted that are now part of the collection.

I was proud to join President Trump today as he signed an executive order to roll back the EPA's Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule. I've been fighting to overturn this rule because Arkansans don’t need bureaucrats in Washington telling them how to use their land. it This is welcome relief for homeowners, small businesses and family farms throughout the country whose ability to use their property was threatened by this EPA overreach. I applaud President Trump for taking this step to protect the private property rights of citizens, especially farmers and ranchers in Arkansas and across the country.

This week I’m meeting with Arkansas members of the American Legion, Disabled American Veterans and Veterans of Foreign Wars as these Veteran Service Organizations share their legislative priorities with members of the Senate and House Veterans’ Affairs Committees. Today, we heard the legislative presentation of the Disabled American Veterans. I appreciate the recommendations and look forward to working with my colleagues to improve services for our veterans.
Congressman Bruce Westerman & I giving our reaction to tonight's speech

It's an exciting day in Mississippi County as Arkansas celebrates the grand opening of Big River Steel. Read about what this means to job creation and our economy in this Arkansas Democrat-Gazette / ArkansasOnline.com story.
Today is Read Across America Day. I had the opportunity to share my love of reading with first graders in Ms. Henley's class at Salem Elementary School.

Highly trained law enforcement professionals are the key to securing our nation's borders. That's why Sen. Capito and I spent time today with CBP leadership to learn more about a number of critical training programs that ensure agents can safely and professionally perform their border security mission. The information gathered from the visit and briefing at the Harpers Ferry campus will be of vital importance as we work to draft an appropriations bill that meets the needs of the men and women who put their lives on the line to protect our borders.

I was proud to sign my name onto the APPROVAL Act which I introduced with the Arkansas Congressional Delegation today. This will allow the voices of Arkansans to be included in decisions that impact their land. If a project is not good for Arkansas, our governor or public service commission should have the power to say ‘no’ instead of being cut out of the process and dictated to by Washington bureaucrats.
The Arkansas Congressional Delegation supports states' rights. That's why we sent a letter today to Secretary of the U.S. Department of Energy Rick Perry urging him to review the Clean Line project.

Arkansas members of the American Legion, Disabled Veterans of America and Veterans of Foreign Wars recently traveled to Washington to reaffirm their support for our veterans and advocate for policies on their behalf. Their input is invaluable as we improve VA health care.

I enjoyed meeting Robert & Shreya, two Arkansans who were selected to participate in the United States Senate Youth Program this week in Washington, DC.   The program was established as an "opportunity for talented young people with demonstrated leadership abilities to deepen their understanding of America’s political processes and strengthen their resolve to pursue careers in public service."  I'm looking forward to seeing what great things they will accomplish and am glad they are able to have this unique experience.

I'm Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Homeland Security Subcommittee. Today I delivered this speech in support of the Trump administration’s efforts to take reasonable and responsible steps to address our porous borders and broken immigration system.

This is a well-deserved honor that reflects our appreciation and respect for the men and women who served in Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. I appreciate Senator Joe Donnelly’s commitment to joining me to see this across the finish line.

I support states' rights. Read my opinion piece published this weekend in the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette / ArkansasOnline.com about what the Trump administration can do to show its commitment to states' rights.

ICYMI: Watch my interview with Roby Brock of Talk Business & Politics-Statewide. We discussed the aggression of North Korea and how our country should respond, health care reform and the APPROVAL Act. Watch the interview that aired Sunday, March 12.

I was proud to recognize Springdale School District Superintendent Dr. Jim Rollins. He has made Arkansas very proud and we are so grateful for his leadership and commitment to educating children no matter where they come from or their station in life. I am honored to know Dr. Rollins and look forward to his continued stewardship of the public school system and the positive influence he has on education throughout Arkansas.

In recognition of Women's History Month I'm highlighting the first female President of National Guard Association of Arkansas. Gulf War veteran Colonel (retired) Mary Frances “Frankie” Sears had a well-established nursing career before joining the Arkansas Army National Guard when she was 39-years-old. She brought with her nearly two decades of nursing experience to the nurse corps, serving with the 148th Evacuation Hospital. Sears became active in National Guard Association of Arkansas as a member of the Board of Directors. In various leadership roles, she helped grow the association into what it is today, while breaking through the glass ceiling. She was the very first female in any National Guard Association or any of its territories to become President of a National Guard Association. We are all blessed because of her service in the Arkansas Army National Guard. I'll submit her stories to the Library of Congress Veterans History Project so future generations can hear about her service to our nation.

My office is hosting a workshop to train Arkansans interested in preserving the memories of our veterans for the Library of Congress Veterans History Project. My staff will be at the Plantation Agriculture Museum State Park in Scott this Saturday at 1 p.m. RSVP to reserve your seat and the learn how you can help collect and share the stories of these heroes.

I enjoyed meeting with members of the Arkansas State Chamber of Commerce/Associated Industries of Arkansas this morning to discuss issues important to them. We talked about improving the regulatory environment so that businesses can feel confident and look to expand. We also discussed how healthcare, taxes, infrastructure and budget issues impact the economy and how we can work together to improve the outlook so that businesses can succeed, create jobs and increase economic activity.   We were also very fortunate to have my friend and colleague Sen. John Barrasso (R-WY), chairman of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, stop by to share his thoughts on improving our infrastructure and restoring common sense to many of the regulations that the federal government has imposed in recent years that are harming businesses and the economy.
NA

I visited Harps Food Stores in Fort Smith today to highlight hunger relief efforts. I was grateful for the opportunity to hear from students from Southside High School's State Champion DECA students and students from Future School of Fort Smith about nutritional education.  I also spoke with the Arkansas Coalition for Obesity Prevention about the Double Up Food Bucks Program that helps Arkansans afford fresh fruits and vegetables. Combatting hunger and promoting nutritional eating options are important ways to foster healthy lifestyles.

It’s great to see businesses, non-profits and government agencies come together to combat hunger and find new ways to meet the nutritional needs of Arkansas families. The innovative programs I learned about  are encouraging community-based solutions and meeting the needs of SNAP recipients where they live and shop. I appreciate the hard work and dedication of Arkansans who join me in fighting hunger.

I was honored to recognize the service and sacrifice of Vietnam veterans Jimmy Gibbs and Dennis Tompkins during a medals presentation Friday at the Fayetteville Veterans Center. I am grateful for their service and sacrifice to our nation.

Last week I joined Governor Asa Hutchinson in Bentonville to promote Free File, a program that provides free online income tax prep and e-filing to low and  moderate income taxpayers. There is still time to take advantage of this service for 2016 tax filings. Learn more in my weekly column.

We are excited to have many Arkansans visiting Washington for spring break. Today families from Fayetteville, Fort Smith, Jonesboro, Benton and Greenbrier visited my office and took a tour of the United States Capitol. Spring is a great time to enjoy the sites of our nation's capital. Be sure to let my office know if you're planning a trip here so we can help you.

I was honored to receive the "Spirit of Enterprise" award from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce today. Supporting pro-growth policies like smarter energy policy, improving our nation's water infrastructure, providing small businesses with improved access to capital and helping manufacturers compete in the global economy is vital and I look forward to advocating for greater economic growth in 2017. We have the opportunity to do even more to advance the policies that will create jobs, spur investment and grow our economy.

Last week during a veterans roundtable in Fayetteville, one of the top concerns I heard about is the continued inequality of health care between men and women. We’re taking steps to eliminate the barriers women veterans face when seeking care. Today we’re introducing the Deborah Sampson Act.

Warren Blaylock, a friend and true public servant, was a lifelong resident of Crawford County, Arkansas. Warren was a World War II veteran and someone I admired greatly for the vital role he played in his community for decades. Today I delivered this tribute in honor of his life.
NA
The Clean Line Project must show there is a need for its energy. Senator Lamar Alexander said on the Senate floor TVA does not have a need.
Telephone town halls allow me to connect with Arkansans all over the state to discuss topics important to them. I'm hosting a telephone town hall right now. You can listen to the conversation here.
This week I helped introduce The Deborah Sampson Act, legislation to improve health services for women veterans. This story by 5NEWS shows why we need to pass this legislation.
I've long support this project. I'm pleased that the Trump administration approved the long overdue permit for construction of the Keystone XL pipeline.

The Senate Air Force Caucus is committed to ensuring our Air Force personnel have the resources needed to accomplish their missions safely and successfully. Our visit gave us a first-hand look at the vital research and innovation that is undertaken at Wright-Patterson on a daily basis and will guide our work as we seek to ensure our Air Force remains the strongest in the world. Read about the delegation visit Senator Sherrod Brown (D-OH) & I, as caucus co-chairs, led today: https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=press-releases&id=64CAF8E2-7372-4FEB-8B80-A73274C70EB0

I'm pleased to serve as the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works Subcommittee on Fisheries, Water, and Wildlife. You can watch the first hearing of the Congress by clicking the link below. I also welcome Dennis Sternberg of Greenbrier, Arkansas who is testifying before the subcommittee.

Today is Vietnam War Veterans Recognition Day. My staff was honored to attend the Central Arkansas Veterans Healthcare System event on Tuesday to honor these great veterans. I am pleased that Arkansans are showing their gratitude in events throughout the week including a ceremony at the Fort Smith National Cemetery and the "Welcome Home Vietnam Veterans Day" luncheon in Hot Springs Village.

Congratulations to the first class of graduates of the Air National Guard Cyber Skills Validation Course at Little Rock Air Force Base, Ark..  This is a historic day at LRAFB. These graduates are essential to combatting our nation’s growing cyber threat. This cyber training course is an important mission to Little Rock and maintains an important role for Arkansas in preserving our national security. I’m proud of the graduates and the work done to launch this course and train these cyber warriors.  Guard members started the inaugural class on February 7, and on Wednesday the class of 20 was recognized in a graduation ceremony attended by the director of the Air National Guard Lieutenant General L. Scott Rice.   As a co-chair of the Senate Air Force Caucus, I joined the Arkansas Congressional Delegation in fighting for a cybersecurity mission at LRAFB. In 2015, then Secretary of the Air Force Deborah Lee James visited LRAFB to see the unique capabilities of the base.

I started off the day with the 5News morning show. We talked about today's visit with Director of the Air National Guard Lieutenant General L. Scott Rice to the 188th Wing, Arkansas Air National Guard, the Supreme Court nominee Judge Neil Gorsuch and the upcoming Senate confirmation, the Secretary of Agriculture nominee Governor Sonny Perdue and health care reform.

Entering into the Paris climate accord was not in America’s best interest and the previous administration should have never taken that action without seeking the Senate’s advice and consent. I commend President Trump for taking the appropriate steps to make a clean exit from it so we can continue to pursue an “all-of-the-above” approach to meeting our energy needs free of the significant litigation risk created by the agreement.  Typical of Obama-era actions, the agreement picked winners and losers. China, an obvious winner, is allowed to operate without making any significant changes. Meanwhile, the U.S., which was expected to make up 21 percent of all emissions reductions while subsidizing the efforts of other countries, was clearly on the losing side.  It is important to stress that a clean exit from the Paris climate accord will not take away the United States’ seat at the table in future discussions, nor will it detract from our efforts to pursue renewable energy solutions. We need to use everything our nation has been blessed with, including wind, solar, renewable biomass and hydropower to diversify our energy portfolio. Emissions-free nuclear must also play a big role. We will continue to make advancements in these areas and that will not stop once the nation withdraws from this agreement.

The Senate took steps today to strengthen sanctions for Iran and Russia, both of which continue to pose a threat to our national security.  The Senate-passed bill expands U.S. sanctions against Iran's ballistic missile program and targets the regime for its support for terrorism, human rights violations and illegal transfers of weapons. It was amended to include a provision that prevents the easing of sanctions against Russia without Congressional approval and establishes additional sanctions for government-backed efforts to meddle in our elections and for its support of the Assad regime in Syria—steps I fully support.   There is no doubt that Iran and Russia are actively working against U.S. interests. We must have every tool at our disposal to punish provocative actions and violations of international law. There must be consequences for these actions.

I share the President’s desire to see democracy take hold in Cuba, as well as his commitment to ending human rights abuses carried out by the Castro regime. However, a return to embargo-like policies is the wrong approach. We ran this play over and over again for fifty years and the results have not changed.  By rolling back reforms that have benefited U.S. citizens, everyday Cubans and our economy, we are taking a step backward, not forward. It would be more effective to continue an open line of communication and working relationship with a government in need of democratic assistance, instead of shutting them out. Through this approach, we not only trade goods, but ideas. The two go hand-in-hand. I will continue to work with my colleagues to promote policies that help the U.S remain competitive and create jobs at home, while pushing for human rights and democratic change in Cuba.

Today, I chaired a Senate Environment and Public Works Subcommittee on Fisheries, Water, and Wildlife hearing about addressing problems in America’s water infrastructure system. Mike Frazee testified about his experience living without access to a public water system since moving to Rogers in 1990. In 2014, Mike and his family reached out to my office and we were able to connect him with the Water Systems Council which was able to drill wells that brought fresh, reliable drinking water to him and his neighbors' homes. Mike is now a vocal advocate for upgrading and improving water infrastructure systems and offers his help and advice to other Arkansans facing this type of challenge. Mike said it is his hope that "through telling the story of my family’s struggle to secure safe, reliable, drinking water that Congress will put in place policies that will bring affordable drinking water to thousands of Arkansans and millions of Americans who live in our nation’s rural areas."  At the conclusion of his opening statement, Mike shared a portion of this video documenting the Well Water Trust Fund's efforts to ensure that safe, affordable drinking water is accessible which has transformed the lives of his neighbors in Arkansas. The Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs today passed the "Harry W. With today's vote to confirm an appointee to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, the Senate has now confirmed 12 federal appeals court nominees this year. That's a record for a president's first year in office, surpassing presidents Kennedy and Nixon, who had 11 federal appeals court nominees confirmed during their first year in office.  This is a really big deal and should not go unnoticed. Federal courts play a large role in our country and the laws that govern it, especially in how laws and statutes are implemented. Judges help shape the direction of the United States for decades. And, since only a very small percentage of cases reach the Supreme Court, it's even more important to appoint and confirm justices who will uphold the constitution at the circuit court-level.  I want to congratulate the president and my colleagues on their diligent and important work to confirm judges appointed by the president over the past year. We have moved at a record pace and the result is that more judges – who serve on the bench for lifetime appointments – committed to upholding the constitution and ruling on the law as Congress intended it to be followed and implemented will now be serving on federal courts.

The House of Representatives just passed the the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which will deliver tax relief to Americans. I'm looking forward to supporting the bill when it comes to a vote on the Senate floor later today so we can send it to the president's desk.

I proudly voted for the tax cut bill that passed in the Senate. Historic tax relief is not far from being signed into law. This is great news for hardworking Arkansans and it is great news for our state’s economy.  For too long, middle-class Arkansans have struggled in an economy that feels like it is stuck in neutral. Our outdated, inefficient and ineffective tax code has played a large role in preventing a full recovery from taking hold.  Tax reform will change that. It will help hardworking Arkansans keep more of their money in their own pockets by nearly doubling the standard deduction, lowering rates and eliminating loopholes. By permanently reducing the corporate tax rate, currently the highest in the developed world, we will make American businesses more competitive and keep well-paying jobs here at home.  This bill is the push our economic recovery needs to get across the finish line.
